tableNews.headLine: Large asset managers support climate change framework
tableNews.shortArticle:
Eight of the world's largest asset managers have backed a climate change framework to accelerate the integration of climate issues into the management of asset pools. Specifically, investors including BlackRock, Amundi, BNP Paribas, State Street Global Advisors and HSBC Global Asset Management have all endorsed the One Planet Sovereign Wealth Fund Framework to form the One Planet Asset Managers Initiative.

Within the framework, the managers have agreed to share investment practices, publish relevant research and engage with regulators and the broader industry, in order to understand the implications of climate-related risks and opportunities within investment portfolios.

Johanna Lasker, head of official institutions at BNP Paribas Asset Management said: "The eight asset managers collectively account for more than one fifth of global assets under management, and their decision to work together towards the full integration of climate risks and opportunities into investment portfolios represents an important step towards the realization of sustainable markets."

tableNews.headLine: Rice Brothers claim victory in EQT proxy battle
tableNews.shortArticle:
Natural gas producer EQT has revealed in a statement that the dissident Rice Brothers have won control of the company's board, and one of the brothers Toby Rice has been named EQT's new chief executive officer. The vote ended a long-running campaign against EQT's management during which the Rice Brothers suggested the board had mismanaged the company.

From the beginning of their campaign the brothers had the support of two significant EQT shareholders, D.E. Shaw Group and Elliott Management. In the lead up to yesterday's vote, proxy adviser ISS backed the brothers' nominees, and EQT's largest shareholder T. Rowe Price also outlined its support in advance.

EQT's statement said that investors including T. Rowe Price and CalSTRS voted to elect all seven Rice nominees as directors as well as five nominees supported by both Rice and EQT. Further, according to a person familiar with the voting, BlackRock and State Street both sided with the dissidents.

tableNews.headLine: BlackRock blasts UK Stewardship Code
tableNews.shortArticle:
The world's largest investor has criticized the UK's proposed new Stewardship Code, announced recently by the Financial Reporting Council (FRC). BlackRock said that the revised guidelines could put companies off listing in the UK.[[B]]

The revised code would urge investors to reveal more about their efforts to push companies for change. According to BlackRock's response to a consultation on the proposals, this may mean that too much information is disclosed about the way investors and companies have engaged. 

This, the asset manager argued, "may, in fact, instead of raising the bar across the market, prompt some market participants to opt out entirely. This could include companies considering whether to list in the UK." BlackRock insisted that establishing "the trust necessary to support effective dialogue" requires that some conversations stay behind closed doors.

The FRC is the UK's accounting watchdog, but also oversees the country's corporate governance guidelines and stewardship code. The body is due to be replaced with a new regulator after a damning review of its operations concluded earlier this year.

tableNews.headLine: BlackRock to outsource Deutsche voting
tableNews.shortArticle:
BlackRock has mandated a specialised company to cast its votes at the Deutsche Bank AG shareholder meeting this Wednesday. Regulation was the reason used to explain BlackRock’s decision[[B]], with a spokesman saying, “BlackRock appoints an independent fiduciary to vote proxies where we are required by regulation or where there are actual or perceived conflicts of interest.”

Deutsche Bank, Germany’s largest lender, saw its shares fall 3.5 percent to a new record low on Monday. The bank also ended incomplete merger talks with Commerzbank AG last month, and investors are uncertain of Deutsche’s strategy going forward.

The meeting agenda for Deutsche Bank includes a resolution to remove Chairman Paul Achleitner. ISS recommends voting against this ousting, while Glass Lewis recommends abstaining from the proposal. Both advisory firms have recommended voting against the bank’s supervisory board.

Vice Chairman of BlackRock, Philipp Hildebrand, commented on the upcoming AGMs for Deutsche and Commerzbank, saying, “These meetings are not going to be fun for the boards or the management undoubtedly,” adding that the two lenders will need to find “an answer to the business model problem which has been at the core of European banking.”

tableNews.headLine: Bayer's management under fire from shareholders
tableNews.shortArticle:
Executives at German pharmaceutical firm Bayer AG are facing considerable opposition from a number of large shareholders ahead of the firm's annual meeting later this week. Specifically, shareholders have said they will not support executives and board members in a no-confidence vote, that despite not having legal implications, will raise questions about the future of Bayer's chief executive Werner Baumann.

The opposition is centered around Bayer's acquisition of US agriculture firm Monsanto last year. Lawsuits and health concerns connected with Roundup, Monsanto's weedkiller product, have caused Bayer's share price to plummet by 38 percent. Ingo Speich of Deka Investment, one of Bayer's disgruntled shareholders, said: "In all good conscience, we can’t exculpate management if so much shareholder value is destroyed."

According to people close to the matter, fellow shareholders BlackRock and DWS, the asset manager of Deutsche Bank, are both intending to abstain from the vote. Proxy advisers Glass Lewis and Institutional Shareholder Services have both called for a vote of no confidence in Mr Baumann and other senior executives.

tableNews.headLine: LGIM tighten overboarding stance
tableNews.shortArticle:
The UK’s largest fund manager, Legal & General Investment Management (LGIM), has updated its voting policy to take a tougher stance on overboarding, joining BlackRock and Vanguard in tightening their guidelines on this issue. 

Sacha Sadan, director of corporate governance at LGIM, said, “If you are the chief executive of a big business, it’s very difficult for you to have many other outside roles… The increased figures reflect the higher standards we expect companies to adhere to.” 

LGIM is a £1tn investment group and has updated its global voting policy to state that executive directors should not take on more than one outside non-executive director role. In January, BlackRock also changed its voting guidelines for Europe, Africa and the Middle East, requiring companies to provide explanation when independent directors serve on more than three other public boards, and when chairmen serve on more than two other boards.

In 2018 LGIM voted against the re-election of 3,864 directors globally, 37 percent more votes against than the year before. LGIM also voted against audit-related issues in 2018 four times more than in 2017.

tableNews.headLine: Fink urges Japanese companies to consider purpose
tableNews.shortArticle:
BlackRock CEO Larry Fink has written to Japanese companies urging them to consider their purpose. The letter was sent to around 500 listed companies in Japan, all of which can count BlackRock among their shareholders.[[B]]

Mr Fink's annual "Dear CEO" letter, which had already been sent to companies in some other markets, was provided to Japanese issuers yesterday. In the letter, he wrote that when a business "truly understands and expresses its purpose, it functions with the focus and strategic discipline that drive long-term profitability." He went on to say that it will become more and more important for a company to account for ESG considerations and serve all of its stakeholders as wealth moves into the hands of younger generations.

To support these points, Mr Fink referenced a survey of millennials conducted by Deloitte. The survey questioned millennials who work full time and are educated to at least degree level. It found that 60 percent of them believe that businesses should not just focus on "generating profit," but also on "improving society."

tableNews.headLine: Asset managers united against ownership limits
tableNews.shortArticle:
A number of asset managers have united against proposed limits on company ownership. Around two dozen investors, including BlackRock and State Street, have all opposed the idea in comments to the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC).[[B]]

The FTC held a consultation last year on the concept of "common ownership," the idea that when investors have significant holdings across multiple companies in an industry there are fewer incentives to compete or innovate. One academic proposal under discussion suggests that investors be limited to owning one company per sector or one percent of an industry as a whole. Since the consultation, multiple investors have submitted comments to the FTC, opposing the theory of common ownership and urging the Commission to reject the proposal.

One of the firmest critics has been BlackRock. The world's largest investor's letter to the FTC, signed by vice-chair Barbara Novick and Chief Risk Officer Bennett Golub, highlighted efforts by BlackRock to influence company strategy despite broad investment in a sector. The letter also criticized a talk at the hearing by Oxford professor Martin Schmalz, saying he misrepresented the investor's engagement activities.

tableNews.headLine: BlackRock vice chair supports further proxy adviser regulation
tableNews.shortArticle:
According to the Main Street Investors Coalition, BlackRock vice chair Barbara Novick said during an event in early February that proxy advisers should be required to disclose conflicts of interest and allow issuers to refute their recommendations before they are sent out to investors.

Ms Novick's November letter to the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) expressed similar views. This puts BlackRock at odds with many other institutional investors and investor rights organizations, including the Council of Institutional Investors (CII) and the Principles for Responsible Investment (PRI). Many of these investors and organizations see further proxy adviser regulation as an attempt to dilute adviser influence within the corporate governance world.

tableNews.headLine: Imperial Brands chair expected to step down
tableNews.shortArticle:
Mark Williamson, chair of Imperial Brands, is expected to leave the company in the next few months. According to a report in The Times, the tobacco group plans to replace Mr Williamson because of his lengthy tenure chairing the board.[[B]]

Mr Williamson has served as chair of Imperial Brands since 2007. This exceeds the nine-year limit recommended by the UK's latest corporate governance guidelines. According to The Times, the introduction of the new guidelines prompted the tobacco giant to begin succession planning for Mr Williamson, and as a result the company is likely to announce his departure this year.

17.8 percent of shareholders voted against Mr Williamson's re-election at the company's AGM last week, although it is believed that much of this was down to concerns about overboarding rather than tenure. He also chairs another board and serves as both senior independent director and audit committee chair at the National Grid. It is understood that BlackRock, which owns 5.6 percent of Imperial Brands, voted against his re-election. The world's largest investor tightened its rules on overboarding as part of its proxy voting policy updates this year, and Mr Williamson did not meet the new standards.

tableNews.headLine: Letters sent to asset owners and managers
tableNews.shortArticle:
Letters were sent to large institutional asset owners and managers by eight US senators asking them to ensure that the companies in which they invest are doing enough to address global deforestation. Asset owners and managers that received a letter include BlackRock, Vanguard, CalPERS, TIAA-CREF, J.P. Morgan Chase, Prudential Financial, Northern Trust and Fidelity Investments.

In each letter it was stated that risks emerging from deforestation "is in line with your fiduciary responsibility. As such, we are interested in learning what due diligence and risk management procedures your firm has put in place to address and mitigate these risks for both active investments and passively managed funds." The senators expect asset owners and managers to respond to the letter by the start of March. The letter campaign is led by senator Brian Schatz, the co-chair of the Senate Climate Action Task Force. 

According to Jeff Conant, international forests program manager for advocacy group Friends of the Earth: "The fact that leading members of the Senate Climate Action Task Force and the Senate Banking Committee are now pressing the nation's top investment firms on their approach to managing deforestation risks should be seen as a very big deal.... It shows that awareness of the financial sector's ties to forest destruction has hit the political mainstream."

tableNews.headLine: EU lawmakers to possibly constrain large index fund managers
tableNews.shortArticle:
Based on research on common ownership theory carried out by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), European lawmakers are currently looking at the threat posed by large index fund managers.

Common ownership is a theory developed within US academic circles. It argues that passive index fund managers, owning stakes in multiple companies within a sector, are incentivized to constrain competition within that sector. According to the OECD research, the three largest international index fund managers, BlackRock, Vanguard and State Street, collectively own 17.6 percent of 1,662 listed US firms.

Last week, the OECD research was quoted by the European Parliament. The institution stated that higher levels of common ownership would have a "hidden social cost and reduced product competition." For instance, German Green MEP Sven Giegold argued that the "dramatic change in the asset management industry" could be dangerous to the running of a market economy. He went on to call for large index fund houses to be regulated.

These concerns are not new. Last year, EU competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager began looking into the effects of common ownership on competition. The debate  is also at a nascent stage within the US, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) conducting a hearing on the subject of common ownership last month.

Large index fund managers, however, argue that the OECD research is flawed. BlackRock sent a letter to the FTC's hearing on common ownership, stating: "Any debate on ‘common ownership’ should be grounded in accurate and robust analysis. To date, the existing research does not meet this standard."

The index fund managers also contend that the incentive to reduce competition between firms does not exist and that the research does not take into account the influence of proxy advisers over shareholder voting. Speaking on the subject, BlackRock vice-chair Barbara Novick said that attempts to constrain large index fund managers were seeking "to fix a problem that does not exist." She also noted that possible solutions, such as limiting managers to one equity stake per sector, were a "cause for concern."

tableNews.headLine: BlackRock's Larry Fink sends latest letter to CEOs
tableNews.shortArticle:
Larry Fink, chief executive of BlackRock, has written his latest annual "Dear CEO" letter. Mr Fink says that the near-US$6 trillion asset manager will focus on issues such as the environment, diversity and executive pay this year.[[B]]

The letter was titled "Purpose and Profit," and it urged business leaders to take action in a time when "frustration with years of stagnant wages, the effect of technology on jobs, and uncertainty about the future have fueled popular anger, nationalism, and xenophobia."

He continued: "Companies cannot solve every issue of public importance, but there are many – from retirement to infrastructure to preparing workers for the jobs of the future – that cannot be solved without corporate leadership." Indeed, the issue of retirement was one that Mr Fink gave some attention to in the letter, encouraging businesses to help their workers save for their later years. "In doing so," he said, "companies will create not just a more stable and engaged workforce, but also a more economically secure population in the places where they operate."

Mr Fink also said that ESG would become "increasingly meaningful to corporate valuations" over the coming years. Surveys have shown that younger savers place more weight on environmental and social considerations when investing than previous generations have done.

tableNews.headLine: Thermal coal increasingly prominent in asset manager portfolios
tableNews.shortArticle:
According to an analysis carried out by UK-based InfluenceMap, the 15 largest international asset managers have increased thermal coal reserves within their portfolios by 20 percent since the signing of the Paris Accord in 2016. This is despite the fact that the reserves of the 300 largest global fossil fuel issuers have risen only 6 percent over the same time frame. 

Apparently, the main reason for this shift seems to be the growing popularity of passive investing. Ranked by the tons of coal per US$1 million in assets, BlackRock ranks highest among the ten largest fund houses.

tableNews.headLine: BlackRock suggests proxy process improvements
tableNews.shortArticle:
As the SEC continues to review the proxy reforms following the recent roundtable, BlackRock has made suggestions as to how the system could be improved. The asset management giant offered opinions on shareholder proposals and proxy advisers.[[B]]

In a recent letter to the US securities regulator, BlackRock suggested that the shareholder proposal process might "benefit from greater transparency." The firm suggested the SEC should start collecting data on proposals, such as the costs they have incurred, as this could "help in modernising the eligibility criteria for initial submissions."

BlackRock also weighed in on the debate about the regulation of proxy advisers. "Governance services firms play an important support role, helping institutional investors meet their fiduciary responsibility to vote thousands of securities in an informed manner, usually in a very compressed timeframe," BlackRock acknowledged in its letter. However, the firm also said that more "disclosure around potential conflicts of interest and how they are mitigated may be warranted."

The letter was signed by vice-chair Barbara Novick and head of investment stewardship for the Americas Ray Cameron.

tableNews.headLine: Fink predicts big future for ESG
tableNews.shortArticle:
Larry Fink has told the New York Times' DealBook conference he believes every active manager will use ESG lenses in as little as five years[[B]].

The CEO of BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, said using ESG criteria was primarily a question of accessing appropriate data, saying demand from clients was "overwhelming."

Fink defended his letter to public company CEOs at the beginning of the year, in which he called on executives to consider the purpose of their business. "I'm not telling any company what their purpose should be," he told New York Times columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin. "It's up to the companies to identify their purpose."

The Rockefeller Foundation's Saadia Madsbjerg, one of the first to coin the phrase impact investing, called Fink's letter "a true gift to impact investing," citing its influence bringing the discussion from private to public markets.

Fink was also quizzed on his decision not to attend a conference linked to the Saudi royal family, saying it had not cost BlackRock any business to date, and the risk of running a consistent deficit when China held a large amount of U.S. treasuries and could influence interest rates.

"If the path remains the same for the next two weeks we're going to have a full-fledged trade war," Fink said. "Let's hope I'm wrong, let's hope the U.S. and China come to an agreement."

Fink also touched on BlackRock's engagement with firearm manufacturers and retailers. The investor divested its active stakes in a number of gunmakers and engaged with those companies through its stewardship team following a shooting at a school in Parkland, Florida on Valentine's Day 2018.

tableNews.headLine: US investors in favor of sunset provisions for dual-stock structures
tableNews.shortArticle:
A group of US investors, including many of the country's main pension funds and the asset managers BlackRock and T. Rowe Price, plan to ask stock exchanges to introduce sunset provisions for companies with unequal voting right structures.[[B]] 

According to director of the Council of Institutional Investors (CII) Ken Bertsch, the introduction of sunset provisions would represent a compromise between advocates of the one share, one vote principle and stock exchanges attempting to entice companies to list.

Dual-stock structures are popular among US tech firms, allowing founders voting power out of proportion to their stake in the company. Sunset provisions would see the superior voting rights of founders revert to a traditional one share, one vote structure, usually after a set amount of time.

The group of investors will ask Intercontinental Exchange and Nasdaq to require that listed companies choosing to go public with dual-stock structures  surrender them within seven years. Such companies would be allowed to extend the structure for another seven years if supported by a majority of shareholders voting on an equal basis.

tableNews.headLine: BlackRock plans to become leader in sustainable investment
tableNews.shortArticle: According to BlackRock chief executive Larry Fink, the asset manager intends to be at the forefront of sustainable investment. The world's largest fund house has recently launched a number of exchange traded funds (ETFs) incorporating ESG criteria.[[B]] The $7 billion BlackRock currently invests in these socially-conscious ETFs is already approximately a quarter of the global total. Mr Fink expects the $25 billion market to expand to over $400 billion in the next ten years. Speaking to the Financial Times, he said that "Sustainable investing will be a core component for how everyone invests in the future....We are only at the early stages." BlackRock's enthusiasm for ETFs incorporating ESG criteria has been seen as an attempt by the asset manager to capitalize on two rising trends in the investment world. Firstly, the proliferation of low-cost, passive investing and secondly the increasingly widespread enthusiasm among institutional investors for the incorporation of ESG factors into investment processes. BlackRock's assets under management continue their inexorable rise, now a colossal $6.4 trillion.

tableNews.headLine: BlackRock clarifies its position on the FRC
tableNews.shortArticle: In a letter to the editor, the world's largest asset manager asserted that its position, as presented in the Financial Times article 'BlackRock under fire for backing watchdog', was not fully reflective of its stance on the future of the UK Financial Reporting Council (FRC). According to Vice-chair Barbara Novick, the article suggests that BlackRock is not in favor of overhauling the FRC's oversight regime. In the letter, Ms Novick reiterates BlackRock's support for the FRC's operational functions, as the asset manager believes that the institution's corporate governance and stewardship oversight responsibilities fit comfortably alongside its accounting and auditing duties. However, BlackRock does advocate the significant reforming of these functions, even though its position falls short of a parceling out of the institution's responsibilities to other bodies. In its independent review, BlackRock outlined that the FRC should better align its duties with its mission and highlighted the need for better regulation and oversight with regards to auditing and accounting practices. The asset manager is also in favor of extending culpability for auditing practices to entire boards by gifting the FRC sanctioning powers against company directors.

tableNews.headLine: BlackRock expands its low-carbon strategy
tableNews.shortArticle:
The world's largest asset manager has joined with Wespath Benefits and Investments to contemplate new ways in which it can invest in the low-carbon economy. BlackRock is now looking for opportunities associated with the gradual shift towards the widespread use of sustainable energy. 

Like many other asset managers, BlackRock already offers its clients funds that focus exclusively on companies with low-carbon footprints. However, Wespath goes further, investing in companies that do more than merely have a low-carbon footprint. These include firms that invest directly in renewable energy and companies that use technology to limit the use of natural resources or increase efficiency. Wespath manages $23 billion on behalf of the US United Methodist Church.

Speaking on BlackRock's expansion to its low-carbon strategy, Brian Deese, the asset manager's global head of sustainable investing, said that it is "seeing and will see a greater disruption across a wide variety of industries.... There is a long-term financial upside if you can be a transition-ready investor." 

BlackRock's strategy endeavors to profit from the low-carbon transition and will be managed on a passive basis. Wespath will allocate $750 million to the strategy. Although it is currently in its testing phase, BlackRock is already considering whether to offer the strategy to the rest of its clients.

tableNews.headLine: BlackRock backs embattled British regulator
tableNews.shortArticle:
Investment giant BlackRock has spoken up in support of the UK's audit and accounting regulator, the Financial Reporting Council (FRC). The FRC is currently under review, with some calling for it to be reformed.[[B]]

In its response to the review, led by Legal & General chair Sir John Kingman, BlackRock has insisted that there should not be "wholesale changes" to the UK's accounting watchdog. The multi-trillion-dollar asset manager has also called for the FRC's powers to be expanded. BlackRock said that the FRC, which also oversees corporate governance in the UK, should have the power to investigate any director of a company. Currently, the watchdog can only investigate directors if they are also registered as either accountants or actuaries.

The FRC has itself called for its powers to be expanded. A number of accountants recently issued a similar call, arguing that the regulator could better oversee companies if it had stronger powers to investigate directors and executives. BlackRock also suggested that the FRC would benefit from having more resources at its disposal, particularly for investigating "grey areas" where "a series of individually legitimate accounting practises... taken together, give rise to a misleading picture of a company’s health."

tableNews.headLine: Fund managers hold UK directors to account
tableNews.shortArticle:
Proxy Insight data has shed some light on those asset managers most willing to hold UK directors to account. BlackRock, Legal & General Investment Management (L&G), Aviva Investors and UBS Asset Management were revealed to be among the most rebellious large managers.[[B]]

According to L&G's director of corporate governance, Sacha Sadan, the fund house voted against directors at UK firms for various reasons, including overboarding, executive pay and a lack of board diversity. He also expects that resistance will grow in the coming years, as investors increasingly vote against culpable directors directly on their re-election proposals rather than merely opposing the relevant resolutions.

Director of corporate governance at FTI Consulting, Peter Reilly echoed Mr Sadan's last point, arguing that investors are increasingly singling out directors for dissent if they believe that the pace of change is too slow: "Chairs of each key committee are in the line of fire. They are easily identifiable and have taken on additional responsibility. They are supposed to take an active role and to spur action in an active way. The threat of going to an AGM and being voted down would be significant for a director."

tableNews.headLine: 2017 sees rise in CEO pay for asset managers
tableNews.shortArticle:
A study by FTfm has compared the remuneration of US and European CEOs at asset managers for 2017. The general trend was record earnings for CEOs during a year that also saw annual profits reach new heights. 

It must be noted that transparency surrounding asset manager executive pay remains generally poor. Only a small number of asset managers disclose the remuneration of their executives. Despite this, FTfm managed to compare the executive pay of many asset managers to their respective revenues. 

Presented as a ratio, Mario Gabelli, the majority owner of Gamco, tops the list (1925:1). In 2017, he received $69.4 million despite the small size of his company. This was equal to approximately 43 percent of the company's operating profits and more than double the $28 million earned by BlackRock's Larry Fink, CEO of the world's largest asset manager. Amundi's Yves Perrier was at the bottom of the list, his salary rising to €2.58 million in 2017. Mr Perrier's pay to revenue ratio was 9.5:1.
